headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half International conference call to discuss first quarter 2010 financial results. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, Presi
componenttext: Hello, and welcome to the Robert Half International conference call to discuss first quarter 2010 financial results. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon. We appreciate your joining us. Before we begin our prepared remarks, I would like to make customary comments on the call to the effect that this call contains predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. Thes
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon. We appreciate your joining us. Before we begin our prepared remarks, I would like to make customary comments on the call to the effect that this call contains predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds, they include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance, and similar expressions. While we believe these remarks to be reasonable, they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. We've described some of these risks and uncertainties in the press release issued today and in our SEC filings. We assume no obligation to update the statements made in this conference call.
Now let's review the first quarter results. Revenues for the first quarter were $737 million, down 10% from the first quarter of last year. Income per share for the quarter was $0.05, down 7% from the first quarter of 2009. Cash flow from operations was $15 million during the quarter. Capital expenditures were $8 million. 
In January, we raised our quarterly cash dividend to $0.13. Our total dividend paid to stockholders was $20 million during the first quarter. We are beginning to see improvement in the demand for our professional staffing services as a result of better economic conditions in North America and abroad.
First quarter revenues for our staffing operations were up 2% on a constant currency basis from the results we reported for the fourth quarter. Our permanent placement operations performed particularly well during the quarter, growing 9% on a constant currency basis versus the fourth quarter of 2009. We believe this relates directly to the depth and the severity of personal cuts made during the recession. Many businesses have had to hire the first sign of a pickup in demand as well as immediately replace workers lost due to turnover. 
At this point, I'll turn the call over to Keith for more detailed review of our first quarter financial results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Max. Let's start with company-wide revenues. As Max indicated, reported revenues in the first quarter were $737 million, down 10% from the first quarter of 2009 and essentially flat on a reported basis, sequentially. There were 62 billing days in
componenttext:
Thanks, Max. Let's start with company-wide revenues. As Max indicated, reported revenues in the first quarter were $737 million, down 10% from the first quarter of 2009 and essentially flat on a reported basis, sequentially. There were 62 billing days in the first quarter, the same as the first quarter of 2009 and the same as last quarter. 
Revenues for Accountemps were $289 million in the first quarter. This is down 12% from a year ago and flat sequentially. Accountemps as our largest Staffing division accounts for 39% of company revenues. There are 360 Accountemps locations worldwide. 
OfficeTeam had revenues of $141 million in the first quarter. This is down 3% from the first quarter of 2009 and also flat sequentially. OfficeTeam is our Administrative Staffing division. It represents 19% of company revenues and [Audio Gap] locations worldwide. 
First quarter revenues for Robert Half Management Resources were $93 million. This is an 18% decline from one year ago and a 3% increase sequentially. This division places senior-level accounting and finance professionals on a project basis. It has 149 locations worldwide and makes up 13% of company revenues.
Robert Half Technology had first quarter revenues of $75 million, down 10% from the first quarter of 2009, and down 1% sequentially. Robert Half Technology places information technology professionals on a consulting and full-time basis. It operates 112 locations worldwide and accounts for 10% of company revenues.
Our Permanent Placement division, Robert Half Finance & Accounting, had revenues of $49 million in the first quarter. This is a decline of 3% from the first quarter of last year and an increase of 7% sequentially. This business was established in 1948, operates 360 locations worldwide. It accounts for 7% of company-wide revenues. 
International staffing operations had revenues of $191 million, down 7% from the first quarter of 2009 and flat sequentially. On a constant currency basis, revenues for our international staffing operations were down 16% compared to the first quarter of last year, but up 4% sequentially. We have staffing operations in 103 locations in 20 countries outside the U.S. International staffing operations represent 29% of total staffing revenues.
First quarter revenues for Protiviti were $90 million, 11% lower than one year ago and 6% lower than last quarter. Formed in 2002, Protiviti is a global business consulting and internal audit firm, providing risk advisory and transaction services. It has 61 locations in 17 countries and accounts for 12% of total RHI revenues. Protiviti's international operations represent 29% of total Protiviti revenues.
Turning to gross margin. First quarter gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations was $201 million or 33.6% of applicable revenues. This compares with 34.7% of revenues for the first quarter of 2009 and 34.5% of revenues for the fourth quarter of 2009. The first quarter sequential decline is the result of higher state unemployment insurance cost and the absence of prior-quarter workers' compensation credits. This was partially offset by higher temp-to-hire conversion fees. 
Overall, staffing gross margin was $250 million for the first quarter or 38.6% of staffing revenues. This includes the gross margin from our temporary and consulting operations, as well as our Permanent Placement divisions, which grew from 7.1% to 7.5% of staffing revenues during the quarter.
First quarter gross margin for Protiviti was $18 million or 20.6% of Protiviti revenues. This compares to 10.4% of revenues in Q1 2009 and 28.7% of revenues in the fourth quarter of 2009. Gross margins declined from the fourth quarter largely due to seasonal factors. These included lower revenues and lower payroll credits for less time charged the vacation and holiday accruals. Protiviti's direct costs for the quarter were down $19 million versus a year ago and up $3 million sequentially or 21% and 5%, respectively.
Turning to selling, general and administrative costs. Staffing SG&A costs for the quarter were $230 million or 35.5% of staffing revenues. This compares to $247 million, a 34.3% of revenues for the first quarter of 2009, and $229 million or 35.7% of revenues for the fourth quarter of 2009. Staffing SG&A costs for the quarter were down $17 million versus one year ago, and up $1 million sequentially or 7% and 0%, respectively. First quarter SG&A costs for Protiviti were $26 million or 29% of revenues. This compares to $30 million or 29.2% of revenues for the first quarter of 2009 and compares to $27 million or 28.4% of revenues for the fourth quarter of 2009. Protiviti SG&A costs for the quarter were $4 million lower than one year ago and $1 million lower than last quarter.
Operating income in the first quarter from our Staffing divisions was $20 million or 3.1% of staffing revenues. The Temporary and Consulting divisions contributed 17 of this amount or 2.8% of applicable revenues. First quarter operating income for our Permanent Placement division was $3 million or 6.4% of applicable revenues. The operating loss for Protiviti was $7.6 million in the first quarter or 8.5% of revenues. 
Protiviti is engaged with demand during the quarter, was strong in IT security, IT application controls, merger, integrations and restructurings. Accounts receivables were $373 million at the end of the fourth quarter, with implied days outstanding or DSO of 46.1 days compared to 45.5 days at the end of the first quarter one year ago.
Now let's turn to guidance. Here are the trends we observed in our business during the first quarter and the first weeks of April. On a same-day sequential basis, revenue from our Temporary and Consulting divisions decreased in January, decreased in February and increased in March. Revenues for our Permanent Placement operations decreased in January, increased in February and increased again in March. 
During the first three weeks of April, revenues from our Temporary and Consulting businesses were down 3% compared to the same period last year. For the first three weeks of April, revenues from our Permanent Placement division were up 28% compared to the same period last year. 
As we've said before, it's difficult to gauge perm trends over such short periods of time. Taking into account these trends and the improving but still uncertain economy, we offer the following second quarter guidance: Revenues, $730 million to $780 million; income per share, $0.03 to $0.08. As you know, we limit our guidance to one quarter. The estimates we provided on this call are subject to the risks mentioned in today's press release. 
I'll turn it back to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. We were pleased with our first quarter results. While the quarter started slowly, we picked up momentum as the quarter progressed. Unemployment levels remained fairly high in the United States and to some of our other geographies, but we
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. We were pleased with our first quarter results. While the quarter started slowly, we picked up momentum as the quarter progressed. Unemployment levels remained fairly high in the United States and to some of our other geographies, but we have started to see renewed staffing demand. 
As we noted earlier on the call, we were particularly pleased with the performance of our Robert Half Finance & Accounting, Permanent Placement division. Many companies that made deep personnel cuts during the recession are having to quickly hire as business demand grows or when they lose workers through turnover. 
We are optimistic about our business prospects as the economy continues to gain momentum. As we have discussed on prior calls, we've kept our domestic and international office networks largely intact. We've retained our best people. We are supporting our strong brand names through marketing activities. And we've invested in technology to further increase productivity in our field operations. 
Protiviti has diversified its revenue base by strengthening its client relationships and expanding its service offerings in areas such as IT, security, IT applications controls, business continuity and infrastructure management. We are also encouraged by the joint opportunities we are seeing as a result of collaboration between Protiviti and our Staffing divisions. We do believe that one effect of this recession has been the wider adoption by companies of flexible staffing models. In a difficult economy, the benefit of having variable labor costs becomes very clear. For the small and mid-sized businesses that make up the largest percentage of our client base, this type of staffing flexibility can be inviable. 
At this time, Keith and I will be happy to respond to questions. We ask that you please limit yourself as usual to one question and a single follow-up as needed. If you have additional questions, we'll certainly try to return to you later in the call.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Tim McHugh with William Blair & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Tim McHugh with William Blair & Company.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering, Keith, if you could elaborate a little bit on the state unemployment taxes. How much of that has been pushed through? And then how that impacts that as well as the improvement in temp-to-perm conversion fees impact. How you'd expect gross
componenttext: I was wondering, Keith, if you could elaborate a little bit on the state unemployment taxes. How much of that has been pushed through? And then how that impacts that as well as the improvement in temp-to-perm conversion fees impact. How you'd expect gross margin to play it out over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say on balance, we did better passing through the unemployment costs than we had projected. You note that our sequential change in temp gross margins was down 75 basis points. That effectively is a combination of 100 basis point decline due to unemplo
componenttext: I'd say on balance, we did better passing through the unemployment costs than we had projected. You note that our sequential change in temp gross margins was down 75 basis points. That effectively is a combination of 100 basis point decline due to unemployment plus the absence of the workers comp credit we got during the fourth quarter. And we got a 25 basis point pickup in conversions. Now going forward, the conservative thing to do was to model flattish gross margins for the next quarter or so. On the one hand, we do expect to continue to make more progress passing through unemployment. That said, the conversions can be volatile. And therefore, to be conservative, I wouldn't necessarily assume we'll see that kind of bump in conversions, although it's quite possible.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: How far have conversion fees come back for you? Can you give us a sense to the magnitude? I know they were highly depressed. Are they just barely off the bottom? Or have they spiked back up to normalized type of levels yet?
componenttext: How far have conversion fees come back for you? Can you give us a sense to the magnitude? I know they were highly depressed. Are they just barely off the bottom? Or have they spiked back up to normalized type of levels yet?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: They've gone from highly depressed to depressed. And so, they're still very low.
componenttext: They've gone from highly depressed to depressed. And so, they're still very low.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citigroup.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Phil Stiller on for Ashwin. I was wondering if you could discuss the expected impact of the healthcare reform on your business?
componenttext: This is Phil Stiller on for Ashwin. I was wondering if you could discuss the expected impact of the healthcare reform on your business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, healthcare reform and the requirement to either provide coverage or pay an excise tax doesn't become effective until 2014. That, sometime in the future, we believe much could change before then. There is a staffing industry, a lobbying
componenttext: Well, as you know, healthcare reform and the requirement to either provide coverage or pay an excise tax doesn't become effective until 2014. That, sometime in the future, we believe much could change before then. There is a staffing industry, a lobbying group, that is very active and planning to get more active as we speak because the bill that was drafted doesn't fit very well into the type of employees we have, i.e., temporary employees. Further, given how it's currently drafted, it's very hard to estimate what the cost is going to be because all of the following have to be met before we have to pay the excise tax. First, our temporaries have to average 30 hours per week for a given month. Second, they actually have to enroll in state insurance exchanges. And finally, they have to have their income below certain thresholds. All of which have to be present before we're obligated to pay the excise tax. I think the biggest uncertainty is what portion of our temporaries will opt into the state exchanges versus what portion will opt to pay the personal penalty. Understand that at least initially, that personal penalty is only 1% of your income, and further understand that because you can't be excluded due to preexisting conditions, you effectively can wait until you get sick to sign up. Many pundits believe that for those reasons, many will in fact opt for the personal penalty, which would totally alleviate our costs on their behalf. The point being, it's really or there's absolutely no way to guesstimate how many will opt for the exchanges versus opt to pay the penalty. And furthermore, because there's another three years until it becomes effective, trust me, there's going to be plenty of attempts to change and make this bill more appropriate for firms such as ourselves.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttext: We have a policy we make available to temporaries that is at their costs. Very few choose that either because they are covered by their spouses' plan, they are covered by COBRA from their prior employer or they simply opt not to incur the costs.

componenttext: Pricing, year-over-year, prices were down at 4.8%. That's roughly in line with what it was last quarter. Sequentially, compared to last quarter, prices, notionally, were down 1.4%. I would observe that we noticed in our Accountemps operation, particularly, that our more transactional positions, which carry lower bill rates, did better than did the higher level positions, meaning, there was a mixed impact in that minus 1.4 %.

componenttext: And then lastly, on the balance sheet, you guys have about $350 million in cash on the balance sheet. You didn't do a buybacks this quarter. Could you comment on what level of cash you think is appropriate, and what you want to do with that cash?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Long term, our strategy doesn't change. We continue to look for opportunistic acquisitions. We've also been fairly consistent in returning cash to shareholders either through dividends or as repurchases. We bumped our dividends this quarter. As Max said,
componenttext: Long term, our strategy doesn't change. We continue to look for opportunistic acquisitions. We've also been fairly consistent in returning cash to shareholders either through dividends or as repurchases. We bumped our dividends this quarter. As Max said, we spent $20 million of our cash flow for that purpose. We will continue to buy back stock over time. We just chose this quarter not to do so.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Kelly Flynn with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Kelly Flynn with Credit Suisse.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So a fair amount has been made in this recovery of the thesis that companies are going to favor temps over permanent employees due to the shell shock of the recent downturn and related themes. Your perm turnaround is quite striking. I'm wondering, in ligh
componenttext: So a fair amount has been made in this recovery of the thesis that companies are going to favor temps over permanent employees due to the shell shock of the recent downturn and related themes. Your perm turnaround is quite striking. I'm wondering, in light what you're seeing in perm versus temp, if you might revisit that thesis and give us any related thoughts.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, the good side of that thesis is that perms doing much better early in the cycle relatively to temp that it has in times past. And as we said in our comments, we believe, because many companies cut so deeply, they are aggressively, at least,
componenttext: Well, clearly, the good side of that thesis is that perms doing much better early in the cycle relatively to temp that it has in times past. And as we said in our comments, we believe, because many companies cut so deeply, they are aggressively, at least, reinstating to those levels when they either get more demand or they have turnover. As to how it impacts temp, traditionally, light industrial and manufacturing lead the professional level temporaries. Whether that will play out this time or not remains to be seen, but that's typically the traditional pattern. Clearly, perm is stronger, and we're pleased that perm is stronger than you would expect it to be at this time.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: All I would add to that, Kelly, is that we said in one of our prior conference calls that we've had an internal program in terms of our marketing efforts in which we're stressing to our small and mid-size clients that the quality of candidates available h
componenttext: All I would add to that, Kelly, is that we said in one of our prior conference calls that we've had an internal program in terms of our marketing efforts in which we're stressing to our small and mid-size clients that the quality of candidates available has never been higher. And to the extent they want to upgrade their staffs, this is an outstanding time to hire people that, frankly, they may not have been able to attract otherwise. So it's hard to say how much of our success is due to that program and how much is due to other factors. But my guess is they're all involved in the success so far.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Just going back to that, well, the thesis I've been talking about has served the opposite of what you're seeing. A lot of people are saying that they think perm is going to lag temp because companies are going to want or lag temp by a greater margin than
componenttext: Just going back to that, well, the thesis I've been talking about has served the opposite of what you're seeing. A lot of people are saying that they think perm is going to lag temp because companies are going to want or lag temp by a greater margin than it normally does because companies are going to feel more comfortable using temps because of all the turmoil we've seen over the last couple of years. And I just want know, is it fair to say that's not how you see it?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the numbers speak for themselves. And at least so far, it says, companies cut so deeply, they're willing to reinstate part of that permanently. I think the numbers speak for themselves so far.
componenttext: I think the numbers speak for themselves. And at least so far, it says, companies cut so deeply, they're willing to reinstate part of that permanently. I think the numbers speak for themselves so far.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you go into the Protiviti losses a little bit more? Was there anything in there that would be one time in nature in the first quarter? And how do you see Protiviti and Protiviti margins faring in the second quarter?
componenttext: Could you go into the Protiviti losses a little bit more? Was there anything in there that would be one time in nature in the first quarter? And how do you see Protiviti and Protiviti margins faring in the second quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: So in the first quarter, Andrew, we did have some severance costs related to our non-U.S. operations. And those severance costs were over $1 million, that we would consider nonrecurring. The second quarter, we would expect a return to profitability in the
componenttext: So in the first quarter, Andrew, we did have some severance costs related to our non-U.S. operations. And those severance costs were over $1 million, that we would consider nonrecurring. The second quarter, we would expect a return to profitability in the United States. We expect improving operations outside the United States. They may still have a small loss. So overall, our thinking is, Protiviti will be breakeven to having another small loss. But clearly, an improvement over what was just reported. As we said in our remarks, the first quarter is Protiviti's seasonally slowest quarter. And that played out again, and it not only impacts revenues, but because you charge less of your payroll to vacation and holiday accruals, your payroll cost that you report in your P&L actually increased as well.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And how do you see revenue trending for Protiviti in the second quarter versus the first?
componenttext: And how do you see revenue trending for Protiviti in the second quarter versus the first?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We see it up. And even if you look at the seasonal softness in the first quarter just ended and if you look back over time, it was not unusual to see double-digit sequential declines. This quarter was better than that. This quarter was only 6%, I believe,
componenttext: We see it up. And even if you look at the seasonal softness in the first quarter just ended and if you look back over time, it was not unusual to see double-digit sequential declines. This quarter was better than that. This quarter was only 6%, I believe, and that's in large part because they've done a really nice job of diversifying away from a focus on Sarbanes-Oxley.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: But wouldn't say that Protiviti second quarter, particularly is the best quarter, right, seasonally speaking?
componenttext: But wouldn't say that Protiviti second quarter, particularly is the best quarter, right, seasonally speaking?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely not. The second half seasonally is much better for Protiviti. But the current thinking for the second quarter is that they will see sequential improvement in their revenues both in the United States and outside the United States.
componenttext: Absolutely not. The second half seasonally is much better for Protiviti. But the current thinking for the second quarter is that they will see sequential improvement in their revenues both in the United States and outside the United States.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Sara Gubins with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Sara Gubins with Bank of America.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a bit about who is doing the hiring that's driving your Perm business?
componenttext: Could you talk a bit about who is doing the hiring that's driving your Perm business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It's our small business client. It's broad based. It's not necessarily any one vertical. Maybe financial services is a little stronger than some of the other industries, but it's -- the costs were so diversified at the client level because of our small bu
componenttext: It's our small business client. It's broad based. It's not necessarily any one vertical. Maybe financial services is a little stronger than some of the other industries, but it's -- the costs were so diversified at the client level because of our small business focus, so is the demand. But what was uniform is how all companies cut very severely their full-time staff. And as we just said, they're certainly willing to reinstate at least some tranche of that.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then separately, you mentioned in terms of priorities for uses of cash, potential acquisitions. Could you give an update on the acquisition pipeline?
componenttext: And then separately, you mentioned in terms of priorities for uses of cash, potential acquisitions. Could you give an update on the acquisition pipeline?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We were, over 20 years, are always looking at smaller deals, new verticals, new geographies, that pipeline continues every single quarter. We would get something that hasn't changed, so the pipeline is there. I think we have a very high bar as far as what
componenttext: We were, over 20 years, are always looking at smaller deals, new verticals, new geographies, that pipeline continues every single quarter. We would get something that hasn't changed, so the pipeline is there. I think we have a very high bar as far as what we actually do, which time shows. But we're still active and looking.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm wondering how multiples are trending at this point?
componenttext: I guess I'm wondering how multiples are trending at this point?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think our view into that market is comprehensive enough to make a statement about multiple trends.
componenttext: I don't think our view into that market is comprehensive enough to make a statement about multiple trends.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Vance Edelson with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Vance Edelson with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: As long as Perm is currently exhibiting a faster growth rate, could you provide a little color on the margin implications from the Perm side of the business picking up, especially if we assume it will continue to be the faster growing business, what impac
componenttext: As long as Perm is currently exhibiting a faster growth rate, could you provide a little color on the margin implications from the Perm side of the business picking up, especially if we assume it will continue to be the faster growing business, what impact do you think that will have on the overall margins?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: You'll have a very good impact. And in fact, if you look this quarter, virtually, 100% of the incremental revenues fell all the way to the bottom line. We've talked about traditional year incremental margins in Perm are more like 35% at least kind of meas
componenttext: You'll have a very good impact. And in fact, if you look this quarter, virtually, 100% of the incremental revenues fell all the way to the bottom line. We've talked about traditional year incremental margins in Perm are more like 35% at least kind of measured it in one-year increments. But this past quarter, the incremental margins were even better for Perm coming off a very low base obviously. So we're very optimistic that we can get outsized incremental margins for Perm as Perm recovers.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a follow-up, how do you expect SG&A to trend from here? You kept it fairly flat sequentially and it's still well below the year-ago levels and the peak levels, and yet you've also managed to keep the sales teams largely intact. So is that a re
componenttext: And then as a follow-up, how do you expect SG&A to trend from here? You kept it fairly flat sequentially and it's still well below the year-ago levels and the peak levels, and yet you've also managed to keep the sales teams largely intact. So is that a reason for optimism that you may be able to continue to contain spending going forward?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the largest portion of our SG&A is the payroll cost for our internal staff. They have very variable compensation plans, so those costs will float with revenues. So as revenues improve, so will the payouts to those people. So rather than looking at i
componenttext: Well, the largest portion of our SG&A is the payroll cost for our internal staff. They have very variable compensation plans, so those costs will float with revenues. So as revenues improve, so will the payouts to those people. So rather than looking at it on an absolute basis, I would look at it relative to the revenues, then we will begin to leverage our fixed cost. But the larger cost is largely a variable cost.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Tobey Sommer with SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Tobey Sommer with SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Frank in for Tobey. Can you give a little color on bill pays spreads and some of the Temp segments in terms of Accountemps, OfficeTeams and Technology?
componenttext: This is Frank in for Tobey. Can you give a little color on bill pays spreads and some of the Temp segments in terms of Accountemps, OfficeTeams and Technology?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: There aren't huge differences relative to the bill rate changes I just talked about in the aggregate because the end customers are largely the same. The spreads by division haven't changed that much. As we said earlier, we were pleased with the amount of
componenttext: There aren't huge differences relative to the bill rate changes I just talked about in the aggregate because the end customers are largely the same. The spreads by division haven't changed that much. As we said earlier, we were pleased with the amount of the unemployment we were able to pass through, we still got work to do, but we're well on our way there.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And can you highlight any areas of geographic strength or weakness in Europe or Asia?
componenttext: And can you highlight any areas of geographic strength or weakness in Europe or Asia?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in the United States, the West Coast and the Southeast didn't have the February storms. So clearly, for the quarter, they did better for that reason alone. If we want to take a quick tour of the world, we did sequentially better in Belgium, we were
componenttext: Well, in the United States, the West Coast and the Southeast didn't have the February storms. So clearly, for the quarter, they did better for that reason alone. If we want to take a quick tour of the world, we did sequentially better in Belgium, we were up in the U.K., we were up in France, we were down slightly in Germany, we were up nicely in Australia, we were down in Japan.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: What was equity based comp for the quarter? And how much is left on the buyback program?
componenttext: What was equity based comp for the quarter? And how much is left on the buyback program?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: On the buyback program, we had a little over 5 million shares. Equity base comp was $14 million, which is about what it's been around and maybe a little bit light of what has been running per quarter.
componenttext: On the buyback program, we had a little over 5 million shares. Equity base comp was $14 million, which is about what it's been around and maybe a little bit light of what has been running per quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Ginocchio with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Revenues came in just below the midpoint of the guidance range, which seems a little unusual for the economic indicators we've been seeing for the last couple of months. Where was maybe weakness versus your expectations three months ago?
componenttext: Revenues came in just below the midpoint of the guidance range, which seems a little unusual for the economic indicators we've been seeing for the last couple of months. Where was maybe weakness versus your expectations three months ago?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we got off to a little slower start in January than we expected. As we talked on the last call, particularly in Management Resources and Technology, your restart projects and getting those restarts to happen is always somewhat challenging. I
componenttext: Well, I think we got off to a little slower start in January than we expected. As we talked on the last call, particularly in Management Resources and Technology, your restart projects and getting those restarts to happen is always somewhat challenging. It was a little more challenging than we expected. You then get to February, which is already a short month. That was exacerbated by the weather in the Northeast. We get to March. We had an extremely good March. We were very pleased with March. We just had too big of a hurdle to overcome with what had happened in January and February.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Any idea what the weather impact was? Can you size that at all?
componenttext: Any idea what the weather impact was? Can you size that at all?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: We're not big on weather impacts. We kind of noted smiling that one of the banking firms did a temperature-adjusted snow analysis and that was more important than precipitation as temperature. So I think that kind of puts into context that we don't go the
componenttext: We're not big on weather impacts. We kind of noted smiling that one of the banking firms did a temperature-adjusted snow analysis and that was more important than precipitation as temperature. So I think that kind of puts into context that we don't go there.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It hurt but we're not going to try to quantify it.
componenttext: It hurt but we're not going to try to quantify it.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: If your tax rate was a little low in the quarter. What do we expect for the rest of the year?
componenttext: If your tax rate was a little low in the quarter. What do we expect for the rest of the year?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Tax rate was low. We had a non-recurring credit of about $1.4 million during the quarter. We would expect the go-forward rate to be lower 40%, 42%, but we did get a little credit [indiscernible].
componenttext: Tax rate was low. We had a non-recurring credit of about $1.4 million during the quarter. We would expect the go-forward rate to be lower 40%, 42%, but we did get a little credit [indiscernible].

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jim Janesky with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jim Janesky with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: It seems, Max and Keith, like now you booked two trends within Perm in your favor. We are hearing that folks are using more temps and then we're hearing that the small- to medium-size business market is pretty weak as well. Are you entirely attributing th
componenttext: It seems, Max and Keith, like now you booked two trends within Perm in your favor. We are hearing that folks are using more temps and then we're hearing that the small- to medium-size business market is pretty weak as well. Are you entirely attributing that? Do you think it just kind of backfilling in jobs? Were folks holding off on senior-level jobs as well? Is there any expectation at that after you back fill in because of the other trends that we're hearing that, that might come back down?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's just simple as companies collectively said, we cut too much. We cut too much and we need to reinstate at least part of that. I think it's no more complex than that.
componenttext: I think it's just simple as companies collectively said, we cut too much. We cut too much and we need to reinstate at least part of that. I think it's no more complex than that.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: As I said earlier, Jim, all I would add to Keith's comment is that, the typical small- to mid-size business owner is very entrepreneurial, and they recognize opportunities when they present themselves. Right now, they do have the opportunity to hire peopl
componenttext: As I said earlier, Jim, all I would add to Keith's comment is that, the typical small- to mid-size business owner is very entrepreneurial, and they recognize opportunities when they present themselves. Right now, they do have the opportunity to hire people they couldn't hire before. Now we've been banging away at that for quite a few months. And I do think some of it is simply they are upgrading, they are hiring people that weren't available in the past to them.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the margins going forward, definitely, that is -- the incremental margins are very high in Perm, but you haven't changed anything to the model or to the pricing structure or to the number of people in there versus the placements that you expec
componenttext: And then on the margins going forward, definitely, that is -- the incremental margins are very high in Perm, but you haven't changed anything to the model or to the pricing structure or to the number of people in there versus the placements that you expect. That should change the trajectory of that, of the margin cycle-to-cycle, right? They should be as strong at the peak in this cycle as they were in past cycles, is that correct?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. There have been no structural changes in how we compensate our business model generally in Perm Placement.
componenttext: That's correct. There have been no structural changes in how we compensate our business model generally in Perm Placement.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick follow up on the compensation, non-cash charge. Is there a separate one than that $14 million, Keith, for restricted stock?
componenttext: And then just a quick follow up on the compensation, non-cash charge. Is there a separate one than that $14 million, Keith, for restricted stock?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That is restricted stock. The option is now de minimis. We stopped doing that in 2004.
componenttext: That is restricted stock. The option is now de minimis. We stopped doing that in 2004.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Gary Bisbee with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Gary Bisbee with Barclays Capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: In the list of areas where you said that Protiviti has seen some strength and engagements, I might have heard it wrong, but it sounded like, three of the four you've mentioned were more sort of technology-based or IT-type skill set. What is the mix of you
componenttext: In the list of areas where you said that Protiviti has seen some strength and engagements, I might have heard it wrong, but it sounded like, three of the four you've mentioned were more sort of technology-based or IT-type skill set. What is the mix of your consultants? I assume people who are doing IT are in also finance and accounting people. Is demand sort of, as you see it unfolding here, positioned with the mix of skill set of your people? Or could we have a situation where demand picks up, but you still have part of the workforce here that's going to be far underutilized for a while?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, the IT area, the IT controls, more specifically area, has been more robust for us. That said, we've had some very good internal audit renewals this quarter. We had a very high profile competitively bid new internal audit win for the quarter
componenttext: Well, clearly, the IT area, the IT controls, more specifically area, has been more robust for us. That said, we've had some very good internal audit renewals this quarter. We had a very high profile competitively bid new internal audit win for the quarter. I guess we didn't mean to leave Internal Audit out. But the facts are that everything Technology related, particularly Technology-development related has been hotter, but we've evolved Protiviti's resource base to match its revenue opportunity. So as we sit here today, we don't have some major out of balance between our resource base and demand.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Is there anything else you're seeing on the horizon here other than just companies may be starting to come back from projects they delayed that could give a jump start to demand for this business?
componenttext: Is there anything else you're seeing on the horizon here other than just companies may be starting to come back from projects they delayed that could give a jump start to demand for this business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, the companies have been particularly tied on many discretionary spending. I think they lose in those first strings and things get better. Even Internal Audit budgets have been under pressure because in companies' quest to save cost, they've
componenttext: Well, I think, the companies have been particularly tied on many discretionary spending. I think they lose in those first strings and things get better. Even Internal Audit budgets have been under pressure because in companies' quest to save cost, they've also reduced their internal audit budgets. I think those begin to come back. We're getting more and more traction with joint staffing and Protiviti engagements, many times staffing introduces Protiviti. The Protiviti provides the project management skills, staffing provides the arms and legs. We've had some very nice wins of nice seven-figure projects, where we've gone to market together. So there are a lot of small incremental wins that collectively add up. We've done well in eDiscovery. We've done well in our restructuring operations. We're bullish about the Protiviti future. We've tried very hard to keep the resource base intact as best we can. Clearly, we could take it lower now and get better short-term results from that. It just seems unwise giving that we're right at the end of the great recession or right at the beginning of the great recovery to make a major further reduction in your resource space. So again, might we lose a few million dollars next quarter because we're hanging tight to our resource base, that's possible. But in the long term, we think that's the right thing to do.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Just the last question on -- from what you can see right now, is there any reason to believe that this business would recover, at say, a different pace than the Temporary Staffing business? I mean are there other different things going on demand drivers t
componenttext: Just the last question on -- from what you can see right now, is there any reason to believe that this business would recover, at say, a different pace than the Temporary Staffing business? I mean are there other different things going on demand drivers that make you think it could come back more quickly?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: What's been really interesting is that, at the top line, for the last couple of years, it's pretty interesting to us how closely the top line for Protiviti has moved with the top line of Staffing. They were in a few percentage points of each other. The to
componenttext: What's been really interesting is that, at the top line, for the last couple of years, it's pretty interesting to us how closely the top line for Protiviti has moved with the top line of Staffing. They were in a few percentage points of each other. The top lines haven't been very different. Protiviti's cost structure is less flexible, and strategically, that's something will work on for the future. But Protiviti's top line hasn't acted much differently than Staffing top line. And that's been on the downside, so I'm not so sure on the upside, it should act that differently either.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin McVeigh with Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin McVeigh with Macquarie.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Keith, if I read your comments right, it seems like Perm is trending a little bit better as is Protiviti on the top line. If we will get the range of the guidance overall, it's probably, as expected, relative to the Street. Are there any areas that are un
componenttext: Keith, if I read your comments right, it seems like Perm is trending a little bit better as is Protiviti on the top line. If we will get the range of the guidance overall, it's probably, as expected, relative to the Street. Are there any areas that are underperforming expectations? Or is this just more conservatism in the guidance?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we try to be conservative. What we reported this quarter was within the range of guidance we gave last quarter. It seems that the better you do historically, the more people jump to the high end or above your guidance. But we always try to be conser
componenttext: Well, we try to be conservative. What we reported this quarter was within the range of guidance we gave last quarter. It seems that the better you do historically, the more people jump to the high end or above your guidance. But we always try to be conservative. Sometimes, it ends up being conservative. Sometimes, it doesn't. So we're just try to call it as we see it.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: What run rate is Protiviti size for now? If you look at the people that are in the unit, what type of revenue could they generate annualized?
componenttext: What run rate is Protiviti size for now? If you look at the people that are in the unit, what type of revenue could they generate annualized?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, using the resource base -- essentially, we broke even in the fourth quarter of last year. We made a little money in the third quarter of last year. We've taken the resources down a little bit from that time. So you don't have to look back ver
componenttext: Well, again, using the resource base -- essentially, we broke even in the fourth quarter of last year. We made a little money in the third quarter of last year. We've taken the resources down a little bit from that time. So you don't have to look back very far to see what the revenue base needs to be for Protiviti to make money. And just like their higher fixed cost structures work against us on the downside, it should work for us on the upside.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Condra with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Condra with BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: Just on the stock comp, really quick, what was your expense in the quarter?

componenttext: That was the number I gave. It was $14 million in change.

componenttext: $14 million for the quarter?

componenttext: For the quarter, that's correct. And that's down, I think, it was $15 million last quarter. I mean, it's been in that range $14 million, $15 million for a few quarters in a row now.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: That's the actual expense from the cash flow?
componenttext: That's the actual expense from the cash flow?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Excuse me?
componenttext: Excuse me?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttext: No, accounting overhaul, it's essentially either provides minimum levels of coverage as defined or pay an excise tax in lieu of that. componenttext: Well, we gave a $40 million to $45 million estimate for the year. The biggest piece of that, we're moving our back-office operations, as we speak, about six miles away. And in fact, for the second quarter, we'll have about $2 million in double rent from one place to the other. But after that, we'll actually have less rent going forward than we pay going in the past.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, traditionally in Accounting & Finance [Finance & Accounting] the second quarter, from a seasonal standpoint, is an okay, not a great quarter. Busy season is over, 10-Ks have been filed, proxies have done, so it's never seasonally a great quarter in
componenttext: Well, traditionally in Accounting & Finance [Finance & Accounting] the second quarter, from a seasonal standpoint, is an okay, not a great quarter. Busy season is over, 10-Ks have been filed, proxies have done, so it's never seasonally a great quarter in Accounting & Finance, generally. It's an okay quarter. Typically, our Consulting divisions, Management Resources and Technology, because the first quarter included a slow start up in January, you have three, four months in the second quarter, so sequentially, you typically do a little better in our consulting operations than you do the other. But it's not by leaps and bounds. So there aren't any big stories seasonal-pattern wise in the second quarter versus the first.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttext: And then when you look at kind of the performance to OfficeTeam in the first quarter and maybe how you expect that in the second quarter, was that business unit, I mean -- results there were pretty decent, I thought. And I was wondering if that was maybe a little bit ahead of where you guys thought it might be trending and maybe what you're expecting going forward?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Traditionally, the office administrative market picks up a little sooner than accounting does. And so it's not totally unexpected that they did a little better. We were pleased with OfficeTeam. And they had a little bit of sequential growth as did our oth
componenttext: Traditionally, the office administrative market picks up a little sooner than accounting does. And so it's not totally unexpected that they did a little better. We were pleased with OfficeTeam. And they had a little bit of sequential growth as did our others. I mean, clearly, we're seeing some improvement across the board. We're seeing more in Perm than in Temp, but we are seeing U.S., non-U.S. improvement. Now the pace of that improvement is a little uneven. It's more measured than we would like. But the traditional pattern would be, what happens in light industrial today happens in Accounting & Finance a couple or three quarters later.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: And then last question just on Protiviti, it seems like an opportunity is there for some pretty good incremental margins at some point at the end of this year and next. Could you just talk about how those incremental margins should trend once you get into
componenttext: And then last question just on Protiviti, it seems like an opportunity is there for some pretty good incremental margins at some point at the end of this year and next. Could you just talk about how those incremental margins should trend once you get into a period where there's a meaningful revenue growth over the break-even point?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, when you're starting at zero or below, the total margins and incremental margins are one and the same. As we've said, if you look back at the history of Protiviti, there was a time when they've had 20% operating margins. It had the highest margins i
componenttext: Well, when you're starting at zero or below, the total margins and incremental margins are one and the same. As we've said, if you look back at the history of Protiviti, there was a time when they've had 20% operating margins. It had the highest margins in the company and life was good. Then Sarbanes-Oxley fatigues set in and life wasn't so good. They've diversified significantly away from that. We don't expect to see 20% operating margins in Protiviti, but we certainly expect to see double-digit or at least 10% operating margin in Protiviti. We've done very, very well in the United States getting back on that path. We've made strides outside the United States. We still have work to do. We're focused on that. We are cautiously optimistic, that consolidated, we can get back to double-digit operating margins, all of which would be incremental.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010

componenttext: Our last question comes from Kelly Flynn with Credit Suisse.

componenttext: Question also relates to Q2 guidance, you're guiding the same that you did for the first quarter, yet you've said that you expect much less of an operating income decline at Protiviti. So I'm wondering what's the offset there? Is there some type of erosion or decline in operating income on the rest of the business that you're [indiscernible]...

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-27-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we expect incremental margin performance across our lines of business in the second quarter. We always hedge that to some degree on the low-side numbers that we give out, just to be prudent. Our current expectation would be that we would see operating
componenttext: No, we expect incremental margin performance across our lines of business in the second quarter. We always hedge that to some degree on the low-side numbers that we give out, just to be prudent. Our current expectation would be that we would see operating income growth in Perm, Temp and Protiviti, or a smaller loss at a minimum in Protiviti in the second quarter and like we back off of that somewhat and get more conservative for the loan numbers we gave out. But at the high end of the range, we have year-over-year growth in every sector for the first time in years, so it would be an inflection point. At the high end of our guidance, we'd have year-over-year growth in Temp, Perm and Protiviti. At the low end of our guidance, we'd have year-over-year growth in Perm and Protiviti, which still be slightly off in the Temp. So we're getting very close to an inflection point at either end of the range.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Robert Half International conference call to discuss second quarter 2010 financial results. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International, and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President, and
componenttext: Welcome to the Robert Half International conference call to discuss second quarter 2010 financial results. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International, and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President, and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind everyone before we begin that comments on this call contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our curren
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. As is our custom, I would like to remind everyone before we begin that comments on this call contain predictions, estimates and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds. They include words such as forecast, estimate, project, expect, believe, guidance, and similar such expressions.
While we believe these remarks to be reasonable, they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. We have described some of these risks and uncertainties in the press release issued today and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs, and today’s 8-K. Our comments today should be considered in light of this press release and the SEC filings. We assume no obligation to update the statements made on this conference call.
Now let's review our second quarter financial results. Second quarter revenues were $769 million, up 3% from the second quarter of last year. On a sequential basis, revenues were up 4% from the first quarter. Income per share for the second quarter was $0.08, up 147% from the $0.03 reported this time last year and up 54% from the $0.05 reported in the first quarter of this year.
Cash flow from operations was $35 million during the second quarter. Capital expenditures were $6 million. During the second quarter, we paid a cash dividend to shareholders of $0.13 per share for a total of $19 million. We also repurchased 2.5 million shares of RHI common stock during the second quarter at a total cost of $66 million. There remain approximately 2.6 million shares available for repurchase under our Board approved stock repurchase plan.
Keith will provide a more detailed review of our second quarter financial results, but I did want to note that we were pleased to see year-over-year and sequential revenue growth during the quarter. We believe this is indicative of improving labor markets in our various geographies. Our OfficeTeam and Robert Half Technology staffing divisions performed particularly well, as did our permanent placement operations. Second quarter revenues for our Robert Half Finance & Accounting permanent placement division were up 29% from one year ago and up 15% sequentially.
Now I will turn the call over to Keith for a closer look at our results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Max. We will first start with companywide revenues. To recap, second quarter revenues were $769 million, up 3% from the second quarter of last year and up 4% sequentially from the first quarter of this year. On a constant currency basis, the ye
componenttext:
Thank you, Max. We will first start with companywide revenues. To recap, second quarter revenues were $769 million, up 3% from the second quarter of last year and up 4% sequentially from the first quarter of this year. On a constant currency basis, the year-over-year and sequential growth rates were 2% and 6% respectively. There were 63 billing days in the second quarter, the same as the second quarter of 2009 and up one day from last quarter. There are 64 billing days in the current third quarter.
Second quarter revenues for Accountemps were $295 million. This is down 5% from a year ago and is flat sequentially on a same day basis. Accountemps is our largest staffing division and accounts for 38% of company revenues. There are 357 Accountemps locations worldwide.
OfficeTeam had second quarter revenues of $150 million, which is up 11% from the second quarter of last year and up 5% sequentially on a same day basis. OfficeTeam is our high end administrative staffing division and represents 20% of company revenues. There are 322 OfficeTeam locations worldwide.
Robert Half Management Resources revenues were $93 billion in the second quarter. This is down 1% from a year ago and down 1% sequentially on a same day basis. Robert Half Management Resources places senior level accounting and finance professionals on a project basis. It has 151 locations worldwide and makes up 12% of company revenues.
Robert Half Technology had second quarter revenues of $82 million, up 9% from the second quarter of last year and up 7% sequentially on a same day basis. Robert Half Technology places information technology professionals on a consulting and full-time basis. It operates in 117 locations worldwide and accounts for 11% of company revenues.
Our permanent placement division, Robert Half Finance & Accounting, had revenues of $56 million in the second quarter. This is up 29% from the second quarter of 2009 and is up 15% sequentially. This business was established in 1948 and it operates in 357 locations worldwide. It accounts for 7% of companywide revenues.
International staffing operations had revenues of $189 million during the second quarter, up 3% from the second quarter of 2009 and down 1% sequentially. On a constant currency basis, revenues for international operations were up 3% compared to the second quarter of last year and up 3% sequentially. We have staffing operations in 101 locations in 20 countries outside of the US. International staffing operations represent 28% of total staffing revenues.
Protiviti revenues were $93 million during the second quarter, up 3% from one year ago and up 6% from last quarter on a same day basis. Formed in 2002, Protiviti is a global business consulting and internal audit firm providing risk, advisory and transaction services. It has 61 locations in 17 countries and accounts for 12% of total RHI revenues. Protiviti’s international operations also represent 28% of total Protiviti revenues.
Now let’s turn to gross margins. Second quarter gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations was $111 million or 34.1% of applicable revenues. This compares with 33.6% of revenues for the first quarter of this year. Second quarter improvement is the result of higher pay bill spreads, higher conversion fees, and workers’ comp accrual adjustment credits of $1.3 million.
Overall staffing gross margin during the second quarter was $268 million or 39.6% of staffing revenues. This compares to 38.6% of revenues for the first quarter of this year. This increase is a result of higher gross margins from our temporary and consulting operations as well as higher permanent placement revenues, which grew from 7.5% to 8.3% of staffing revenues during the quarter.
Second quarter gross margin for Protiviti was $22 million or 24% of Protiviti revenues. This compares to 20.6% of its revenues in the first quarter of this year. The improvement is due primarily to higher chargeability. Protiviti’s direct costs for the quarter were down $4 million versus a year ago and down another $1 million sequentially.
Second quarter staffing SG&A costs were $238 million or 35.3% of staffing revenues. This compares to $227 million or 34.4% of revenues for the second quarter of last year and $230 million or 35.5% of revenues for the first quarter of this year. Second quarter staffing SG&A costs include special charges of $2.6 million related to the settlement of several outstanding litigation claims primarily related to wage and hour labor loss. These cases have been outstanding for many years.
While the company believes - continues to believe it has meritorious defenses, these cases were settled primarily to avoid potentially significant additional cost that would result from protracted litigation. Second quarter SG&A costs for Protiviti were $29 million or 31.2% of revenues. This compares to $28 million or 31.2% of revenues for the second quarter of last year and $26 million or 29% of revenues for the first quarter of this year.
Protiviti SG&A costs also include special charges of $2.4 million to settle outstanding litigation claims, primarily related to wage and hour labor loss. This case covered an eight-plus year period dating back to 2002. While the company continues to believe it has meritorious defenses, these cases were also settled primarily to avoid future litigation costs.
Now turning to operating income. Operating income from our staffing divisions during the second quarter was $29 million or 4.3% of staffing revenues. Temporary and consulting divisions contributed $24 million of this amount or 3.8% of revenues. Quarter operating for our permanent placement division was $5 million or 9.9% of applicable revenues.
The operating loss for Protiviti was $6.8 million in the second quarter or 7.3% of revenues. Excluding the special charges just referenced, Protiviti’s second quarter loss was $4.4 million, an improvement of $3.2 million from the first quarter of this year. Much of this improvement occurred in Protiviti’s international operations. Accounts receivable were $385 million at the end of the second quarter, with implied days outstanding of 45.5 days, which compares to 45.4 days at the end of last year’s second quarter.
Now let's turn to guidance. Following were few of the trends we observed in our business during the second quarter and the first weeks of July. On a same day sequential basis, revenues from our temporary and consulting divisions were down in April, decreased again in May, but increased in June. Revenues from our permanent placement operations decreased in April, increased in May, and increased again in June.
During the first two weeks of July, revenues from our temporary and consulting businesses were up 7% compared to the same period last year. For the first three weeks of July, revenues from our permanent placement division were up 8% compared to the same period last year. As we've said before, however, it is difficult to read too much into perm trends over such short periods of time.
Taking into account these business trends and the improving but still uncertain economy, we offer the following third quarter guidance. Revenues, $770 million to $820 million. Income per share, $0.09 to $0.14. This guidance does not include any amounts for the possible settlement of outstanding legal claims. As you know, we limit our guidance to one quarter. The estimates we’ve provided on this call are subject to the risks mentioned in today’s press release.
Now I’ll turn it back to Max.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-21-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. As previously noted, we were pleased to see our second quarter revenues improve on both the year-over-year and sequential basis. We believe the US economy, while still uncertain, is on a stronger footing today than it was one year ago. B
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. As previously noted, we were pleased to see our second quarter revenues improve on both the year-over-year and sequential basis. We believe the US economy, while still uncertain, is on a stronger footing today than it was one year ago. But the unemployment rate remains high and many companies are managing increased business demand by using temporary workers. This is allowing them to keep their labor costs variable until they are confident their business improvement is sustainable.
We believe there is greater acceptance by companies of flexible staffing models that include a mix of both full-time and temporary workers. Business trends within our staffing operations are in some respects consistent with past economic cycles. For example, we saw strength in OfficeTeam during the second quarter, and it is not unusual for administrative staffing to improve before the Finance & Accounting segments.
The relative strength in technology staffing, we believe, is likely the result of renewed investment by companies in new systems and software following years of postponing information technology investments. What is perhaps inconsistent with past cycles is the continued strong demand for our permanent placement services.
Historically, full-time staffing has been the last to recover from a downturn because companies typically rely first on temporary employees to meet rising workload demands. We have said many times that we felt companies would need to add full-time personnel to make up for the deep personnel cuts made during the downturn. This apparently has been the case at least in our experience.
Our Federal Reserve Chairman stated this morning that the US economy faces “unusually uncertain prospects.” However, if the economy is in fact on the path to recovery, we feel we are in a good position to benefit from increased demand for staffing and consulting services. Historically, we have emerged from economic downturns stronger and growing more rapidly than before.
We feel we have an experienced management team in our staffing operations and in Protiviti, and I am confident in their leadership abilities. Protiviti continues to diversify its business and develop a loyal client base. SOX-related services now account for less than 20% of total revenues of Protiviti. This quarter we saw particular demand in various IT related areas, including IT security and privacy, IT applications controls, and infrastructure management. Protiviti and our staffing brands also are collaborating more frequently and bringing a full suite of staffing and consulting services to our clients.
At this time, Keith and I will be happy to answer questions. We ask that you please limit yourself as usual to one question and a single follow-up as needed. If you have additional questions, we will certainly try to return to you later in the call. Thank you.

componenttext: Mark, it was not included in our previous guidance. During the quarter, we did attempt to clean up many of the outstanding wage and hour law cases we have. If we could do so at reasonable amounts, as previously mentioned, we did this primarily to avoid the cost of protracted litigation even though we continue to believe we do have meritorious defenses. Some of these cases grow back as far as ten years. So they have been around forever. Because the remaining cases involve pending litigation, our attorneys have pretty much told us not to make further comments. That said, as we do every quarter, we update the specifics of these outstanding cases in our Form 8-K and that we filed today just like we always do with our earnings release.

componenttext: I guess based on the settlements we’ve done so far, we wouldn’t see material long-term changes to our model. But that said, clearly the law continues to evolve. We’ve referenced in our disclosures other cases before the California Supreme Court. But again, based on everything we know, we do not expect material long-term changes to our models.

componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more about the strength that you are seeing in perm? Just the behavior is interesting this time around. Do you think it is just because people cut back or that people cut back on their own recruiting capabilities and need are depending on your more?

componenttext: We think people over-cutback. And to some degree, they are having to reinstate levels of cutbacks, and they can do so at a time when the supply of labor has never been better. So it’s a win-win.
