headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you provide us the tax rate that you expect for Q4 and just give a little color about kind of what's going on there given that it's been moving around? And then also just on Perm, can you give a little more color on what your Q4 guidance implies for
componenttext: Could you provide us the tax rate that you expect for Q4 and just give a little color about kind of what's going on there given that it's been moving around? And then also just on Perm, can you give a little more color on what your Q4 guidance implies for Perm, and specifically, address how you're thinking about the tougher comps?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on the tax rate, as we've talked about for a few quarters now, the global composition of our income in some of the foreign locations we still have small losses, all impact are weighted average tax rate. So 42% to 45% for the near term probably isn't
componenttext: Well, on the tax rate, as we've talked about for a few quarters now, the global composition of our income in some of the foreign locations we still have small losses, all impact are weighted average tax rate. So 42% to 45% for the near term probably isn't a bad estimate. And again, there's more volatility to that than there traditionally would be because of the relative importance of foreign operations, earnings, or lack thereof. As to Perm and guidance, the fourth quarter seasonally is always a little bit softer in Perm than the other quarters. Companies run out of hiring budget, companies begin to work on their following year hiring budget and throttle back a bit on their full-time hiring. There's the December effect, and we've lived through over 20 Decembers, and Decembers are particularly hard to predict in Perm. We've have some great ones. We've had some not so great ones. So there's probably more uncertainty with our Perm component of our guidance than any other one line of business. But that said, our people remain bullish on Perm. It's just the typical fourth quarter jitters.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: No, you're exactly right. What happened during the quarter, Jeff, was for our more tenured and productive people, we actually modified the milestone component to their compensation plans to reward them for their tenure and productivity, such that we had higher compensation costs in the quarter than would be typical. We wouldn't expect that to repeat to the same extent in the coming quarter.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say a couple of things. Seasonally, DSOs always stretch out a little bit during these months as our clients' account payable departments aren't as available as they are on holiday. Further, our revenues were particularly backloaded this quarter. Septe
componenttext: I'd say a couple of things. Seasonally, DSOs always stretch out a little bit during these months as our clients' account payable departments aren't as available as they are on holiday. Further, our revenues were particularly backloaded this quarter. September was particularly strong. And if you just do the math, if you've got the revenues that are back ended that has the impact, and that's a good thing to impact your DSO.

componenttext: And then can you give us some comments on -- you talked about the Perm side of SG&A, and you gave some extra comps there. What are you doing on the temp side? headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the temp side, we are beginning to add to headcount. I'd say we added mid-single digit to our headcount during the quarter that was tech-related first and our smaller Accountemps operations where growth began to kick in, where we felt like we were unde
componenttext: On the temp side, we are beginning to add to headcount. I'd say we added mid-single digit to our headcount during the quarter that was tech-related first and our smaller Accountemps operations where growth began to kick in, where we felt like we were understaffed. So we did add to our staff during the quarter, given the results that we had. Along those lines, I would make a couple of points. This is the fastest recovery we've ever experienced post downturn. Our temp business is 20% above its lows versus at the same time in the last upcycle, it was still flat relative to the lows. Our Perm business is 40% above the lows versus same time last cycle. It was also flat versus the lows. Those things said, our Temp business is still only 70% of its prior peak. Our Perm business is only 50% of its prior peak, and many make the case that prior peaks will well be exceeded in this cycle because of the secular shifts. I would also point out, there's a lot of discussion about the late cycle leaders, cycle participation of accounting and finance, and we're happy to report that the lag between accounting and office administrative, as an example, is the shortest lag we've ever experienced. This time around, there was a four- to five-month lag between when OfficeTeam went year-over-year positive in revenues and when Accountemps went year-over-year positive. In the last cycle, that lag was nine to 10 months. So for all of those positive reasons, we’ve begun to add the headcount, starting with technology; and secondly, backfilling the locations that we felt got a little too small in Accountemps.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sara Gubins with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On Protiviti, could you give some more detail about trends in the U.S. versus international?
componenttext: On Protiviti, could you give some more detail about trends in the U.S. versus international?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say the trends in the U.S., there's more seasonality in the U.S. So we got some SOX lift during the quarter. Certainly, not the traditional SOX lift, and SOX year-over-year was still down in Protiviti, as was expected. We're seeing a lot of strength o
componenttext: I'd say the trends in the U.S., there's more seasonality in the U.S. So we got some SOX lift during the quarter. Certainly, not the traditional SOX lift, and SOX year-over-year was still down in Protiviti, as was expected. We're seeing a lot of strength on the IT side, security, privacy, application controls, as Max talked about. So very strong in the U.S. Outside the U.S., you had the Europe August impact, which clearly negatively impacts their numbers and comparisons. But overall, we're quite pleased with the path that Protiviti's been on that has improved quarter-on-quarter for several quarters in a row.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then as a separate follow-up, last quarter, you had broken out Accountemps into two halves where you'd given us some indication on transnational accounting and staff accounting. Could you give an update for how those two halves performed during the th
componenttext: And then as a separate follow-up, last quarter, you had broken out Accountemps into two halves where you'd given us some indication on transnational accounting and staff accounting. Could you give an update for how those two halves performed during the third quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the accounting operations or the lower-skilled part continued to perform well. But what really came on was the finance or staff accounting side, which was running much hotter this quarter, which includes credit and collections, professionals, budget
componenttext: Well, the accounting operations or the lower-skilled part continued to perform well. But what really came on was the finance or staff accounting side, which was running much hotter this quarter, which includes credit and collections, professionals, budget analyst. It's frankly a very traditional recovery to see the transactional positions pick up first, and the higher level or the staff level positions pick up after that. And I would say that Management Resources followed that same trend where we're seeing project work in accounting get traction a little later than did the accounting operations or transactional positions. But very traditional in the timing of when those kick in.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer with SunTrust.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Staying on the Accountemps section, can you talk about what your view is as to why the lag is four to five months this cycle versus nine to 10 months traditionally?
componenttext: Staying on the Accountemps section, can you talk about what your view is as to why the lag is four to five months this cycle versus nine to 10 months traditionally?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there's a greater awareness everywhere that you want variable labor cost that using temporaries is an effective way to do that. With unemployment rates like they are, the quality of the supply of temporaries has never been better. So at the very t
componenttext: I think there's a greater awareness everywhere that you want variable labor cost that using temporaries is an effective way to do that. With unemployment rates like they are, the quality of the supply of temporaries has never been better. So at the very time you want more cost variability, you have the best people available ever. And for that reason, on a secular basis, people are using more temporaries.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of the international staffing, can you speak to any areas of particular strength or weakness or add any color in terms of trends there?
componenttext: And in terms of the international staffing, can you speak to any areas of particular strength or weakness or add any color in terms of trends there?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'd say Australia was our strongest market. In Europe, we were led by Germany but the U.K., France and Belgium were solid. So overall, doing well outside the U.S. and Australia for widely documented natural resource-rich reasons, is leading the grou
componenttext: Sure. I'd say Australia was our strongest market. In Europe, we were led by Germany but the U.K., France and Belgium were solid. So overall, doing well outside the U.S. and Australia for widely documented natural resource-rich reasons, is leading the group.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ashwin Shirvaikar with Citigroup.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you can separate out the behavior of small business clients versus larger clients, are small business clients beginning to unwind a bit from the downturn?
componenttext: If you can separate out the behavior of small business clients versus larger clients, are small business clients beginning to unwind a bit from the downturn?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, given that the lion's share of our clients are small to middle-sized businesses, I think you can pretty much take our numbers as a proxy for their behaviors. While we do have some exposure to larger clients, it's well less than half relative to smal
componenttext: Well, given that the lion's share of our clients are small to middle-sized businesses, I think you can pretty much take our numbers as a proxy for their behaviors. While we do have some exposure to larger clients, it's well less than half relative to small to middle-sized businesses. So clearly, they're using more temporaries. Now whether they're getting more confident about their prospects, we can argue. But it's a fact. They're using more temporaries.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you mentioned in a previous reply, pricing is relatively strong in tech and beginning to get strong in OfficeTeam, or at least getting better. Is there a way to quantify when you say it's positive, is it plus one, plus two, any color there?
componenttext: And you mentioned in a previous reply, pricing is relatively strong in tech and beginning to get strong in OfficeTeam, or at least getting better. Is there a way to quantify when you say it's positive, is it plus one, plus two, any color there?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: They're very de minimis percentages but they stick out in that they're positive relative to the declines we've seen of late in all of our divisions.
componenttext: They're very de minimis percentages but they stick out in that they're positive relative to the declines we've seen of late in all of our divisions.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know it's only been three weeks since the Federal government passed this $30 billion small business lending bill. I'm just wondering if any clients are talking about it. Have you ever seen anything like this before? And if you could try to think about i
componenttext: I know it's only been three weeks since the Federal government passed this $30 billion small business lending bill. I'm just wondering if any clients are talking about it. Have you ever seen anything like this before? And if you could try to think about its impact on you SME customer base?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, it's a net positive. We've made comments on prior calls that the credit crunch or the lack of credit availability isn't the biggest issue our small business clients have had, notwithstanding the headlines. Their biggest issue was demand for the
componenttext: Certainly, it's a net positive. We've made comments on prior calls that the credit crunch or the lack of credit availability isn't the biggest issue our small business clients have had, notwithstanding the headlines. Their biggest issue was demand for their services. But that said, more credit is a better thing rather than not, and we haven't seen any very specific demand come from that, but we will.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there a timeline on that? Or would there be a -- based on if it started working when you’d think you might see a pickup in demand, if there's anything created from this?
componenttext: Is there a timeline on that? Or would there be a -- based on if it started working when you’d think you might see a pickup in demand, if there's anything created from this?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just be speculating.
componenttext: I would just be speculating.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Bisbee with Barclays Capital.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess when I look at the mix of where you got off, it strikes me, it's sort of interesting that you have only a third as many technology offices as you do Accountemps or the Perm business. Given I think some people would argue there's better secular tre
componenttext: I guess when I look at the mix of where you got off, it strikes me, it's sort of interesting that you have only a third as many technology offices as you do Accountemps or the Perm business. Given I think some people would argue there's better secular trends potentially in tech, and certainly, it's doing a little better today. Is that just a legacy issue? Why is that? And what's the plan? Do you have any plans to accelerate adding technology into some of the existing offices?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, traditionally, where we have offices is very candidate-driven and that how many do you need to cover the candidate base. How far are they willing to travel? And if you look at tech firms generally, you don't need as many satellite locations
componenttext: Well, I think, traditionally, where we have offices is very candidate-driven and that how many do you need to cover the candidate base. How far are they willing to travel? And if you look at tech firms generally, you don't need as many satellite locations as you do for some of the other service lines. So I wouldn't expect we would ever have as many locations in technology as we do in Accountemps. Certainly, there's room for more than we have now. And outside the U.S., we certainly have countries that have virtually no presence in technology as we speak. So that's greenfield opportunity. So I'm sure it's less, and it doesn't need to be as much less as it currently is. But that said, I'm not sure it'll ever be the same number. You don't need as many offices in technology. You can cover a wider area with a given office in technology than you can as an example in OfficeTeam.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That having been said, we are clearly focused on expanding our technology business in existing offices and perhaps some others. So I don't want to leave that unsaid.
componenttext: That having been said, we are clearly focused on expanding our technology business in existing offices and perhaps some others. So I don't want to leave that unsaid.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other metric we would follow more closely is what our staff levels rather than how many physical offices do we have. We think there's a huge upside in the staff levels we can have in the geographies where we already exist. So to me, the featur
componenttext: I think the other metric we would follow more closely is what our staff levels rather than how many physical offices do we have. We think there's a huge upside in the staff levels we can have in the geographies where we already exist. So to me, the featured fight is getting appropriately staffed to take advantage of the opportunity, not necessarily having a bigger physical footprint.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given that it sounds like Protiviti has got a growing technology presence there, I'm not sure if you're doing much of that in Management Resources, but can you give us any sense what maybe overall company mix of revenue would be more technology-focused th
componenttext: Given that it sounds like Protiviti has got a growing technology presence there, I'm not sure if you're doing much of that in Management Resources, but can you give us any sense what maybe overall company mix of revenue would be more technology-focused than either the accounting, finance or office segments? I mean, is that getting up towards 20%? And do you have any goals to have that more balanced?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you can quickly do research and determine that the overall technology staffing market is larger than the overall accounting and finance market. And therefore, we think there is a huge opportunity in technology. Traditionally, technology over the y
componenttext: I think you can quickly do research and determine that the overall technology staffing market is larger than the overall accounting and finance market. And therefore, we think there is a huge opportunity in technology. Traditionally, technology over the years has been contract programming at large Fortune 1,000 companies at margin levels that are a bit challenged relative to our typical profile. And so what we're getting after is how can we profitably approach the technology market. And we're pretty encouraged with what we see so far.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh with Macquarie.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Keith, I wonder if you could talk a little bit about the shift on Protiviti towards more variable as opposed to fixed-cost structure across the group overall and how Management Resources plays into that?
componenttext: Keith, I wonder if you could talk a little bit about the shift on Protiviti towards more variable as opposed to fixed-cost structure across the group overall and how Management Resources plays into that?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Protiviti has made tremendous progress in using contractors, consultants for Management Resources. And frankly, from all of our divisions, including RH Technology, all its assignments. There's been a meaningful increase in the variable component of their
componenttext: Protiviti has made tremendous progress in using contractors, consultants for Management Resources. And frankly, from all of our divisions, including RH Technology, all its assignments. There's been a meaningful increase in the variable component of their labor cost, which we're very pleased with because of the inherent seasonality that exists in Protiviti. Second half is always going to be somewhat better than the first half. And so we'd like to be in a position that have our costs flexed just as our revenues do. We're not totally there yet but we've made light years of progress in the last 12 months. We now have a double-digit percentage of Protiviti's total workforce represented by contractors from our staffing divisions.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just real quick on the buyback, it seems like you scaled that back a little bit relative to the second quarter. Any thoughts on that going forward?
componenttext: Just real quick on the buyback, it seems like you scaled that back a little bit relative to the second quarter. Any thoughts on that going forward?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Long term, we're committed to spend our cash flow on repurchases and dividends. And even this year, year-to-date, we've done just that. Some quarters, we turn up the spigot, some quarters we turned down the spigot. But over long periods of time and in fac
componenttext: Long term, we're committed to spend our cash flow on repurchases and dividends. And even this year, year-to-date, we've done just that. Some quarters, we turn up the spigot, some quarters we turned down the spigot. But over long periods of time and in fact, go back five years, and you will find, we've spent almost exactly 100% of our cash flow on dividends and repurchases, and we remain committed to do so.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from the line of John Healy with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of John Healy with Northcoast Research.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Big picture question for you. When I look at your results, as well as your peers, you can clearly see the value proposition behind temp staffing has changed. I was curious to get your thoughts if you think over the next, I don't know if it's the next six
componenttext: Big picture question for you. When I look at your results, as well as your peers, you can clearly see the value proposition behind temp staffing has changed. I was curious to get your thoughts if you think over the next, I don't know if it's the next six months or the next year or two, do you think the value proposition of what you can do on the Perm side of the business is changing and that will your customer see you more as an HR partner than they saw in the past, do you think?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I understand that our traditional middle market account doesn't have an HR department. And when you need an accounting manager or a controller or a business manager, you can't go to HR and tell them to hire them. They effectively outsource that to us, whi
componenttext: I understand that our traditional middle market account doesn't have an HR department. And when you need an accounting manager or a controller or a business manager, you can't go to HR and tell them to hire them. They effectively outsource that to us, which makes sense from them given their size. So I don't think that demand driver changes anything. If anything, it gets stronger rather than not.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: All I'll add is the typical small to mid-sized business person is fairly entrepreneurial. They have pretty sharp pencils, particularly in a downturn such as we've had, and they understand the cost benefits of variable labor. And so I think the concept of
componenttext: All I'll add is the typical small to mid-sized business person is fairly entrepreneurial. They have pretty sharp pencils, particularly in a downturn such as we've had, and they understand the cost benefits of variable labor. And so I think the concept of flexible staffing has been validated mightily in this recession. I think that bodes well for the industry in general and for us in particular.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hello and welcome to the Robert Half International Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Offic
componenttext:
Hello and welcome to the Robert Half International Third Quarter 2010 Conference Call. Our hosts for today's call are Mr. Max Messmer, Chairman and CEO of Robert Half International; and Mr. Keith Waddell, Vice Chairman, President and Chief Financial Officer.
Mr. Messmer, you may begin.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and hello, everyone. Thank you for joining the call today. As is our custom, I would like to remind everyone that comments on this call contain predictions, estimates, and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current
componenttext:
Thank you, and hello, everyone. Thank you for joining the call today. As is our custom, I would like to remind everyone that comments on this call contain predictions, estimates, and other forward-looking statements. These statements represent our current judgment of what the future holds, and include words such as 'forecast,' 'estimate,' 'project,' 'expect,' ' believe,' 'guidance,' and similar expressions. We believe these remarks to be reasonable, but would remind you that they are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. We've described some of these risks and uncertainties in today's press release and in our SEC filings, including our 10-Ks, 10-Qs, and today's 8-K. We assume no obligation to update the statements made on this call.
Now let's review the third quarter. Third quarter revenues were $817 million, up 13% from the third quarter of 2009, and up 6% sequentially from the second quarter. Income per share for the third quarter was $0.14, up 130% from the $0.06 reported in the third quarter of 2009, and up 74% from the $0.08 reported in the second quarter of this year.
Cash flow from operations during the third quarter was $50 million with capital expenditures of $8 million. We paid a cash dividend to shareholders of $0.13 per share during the quarter for a total of $19 million. We also spent $11 million to repurchase 500,000 shares of RHI common stock during the quarter, approximately 2.1 million shares remain available for repurchase under our Board approved stock repurchase plan. We were pleased to see broad-based increases in demand throughout our operations, each of our staffing divisions and Protiviti reported both year-over-year and sequential revenue gains during the third quarter.
I'll turn the call over to Keith for a more detailed look at the third quarter results.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Max. I'll start with companywide revenues. As Max indicated, third quarter revenues were $817 million, up 13% from the third quarter of 2009 and up 6% sequentially. The year-over-year and sequential growth rates were 14% and 6% respectively on
componenttext:
Thank you, Max. I'll start with companywide revenues. As Max indicated, third quarter revenues were $817 million, up 13% from the third quarter of 2009 and up 6% sequentially. The year-over-year and sequential growth rates were 14% and 6% respectively on a constant currency basis. There were 64 billing days in the third quarter, the same as the third quarter of last year. There were 63 billing days last quarter, and the current fourth quarter has 62 billing days.
Accountemps revenues were $313 million in the third quarter, up 9% from this time last year, and up 4% sequentially on a same day basis. Accountemps is our largest staffing division and accounts for 38% of company revenues. There are 355 Accountemps locations worldwide. OfficeTeam had third quarter revenues of $163 million, an increase of 22% from the third quarter of 2009, and an increase of 7% sequentially on a same day basis. OfficeTeam is our hired administrative staffing division, and represents 20% of company revenues. There are 321 OfficeTeam locations worldwide. Third quarter revenues for our Robert Half Management Resources division were $98 million. This is an increase of 9% from a year ago and an increase of 4% sequentially on a same day basis. 
Robert Half Management Resources places senior level accounting and finance professionals on a project basis. It has 153 locations worldwide, and makes up 12% of company revenues. Robert Half Technology had third quarter revenues of $87 million, up 17% from the third quarter of 2009, and up 5% from the second quarter of this year on a same day basis. Robert Half Technology places IT professionals on a consulting and full time basis. It operates in 117 locations worldwide, and accounts for 11% of company revenues. Robert Half Finance & Accounting, our perm placement division had third quarter revenues of $57 million. This is a 33% increase from the third quarter of last year, and a 2% increase sequentially. This business was established in 1948 and it operates in 355 locations worldwide. Our perm placement division accounts for 7% of companywide revenues.
International staffing operations had revenues of $204 million during the third quarter, up 11% from the third quarter of 2009, and up 8% sequentially. On a constant currency basis, revenues for international staffing operations were up 15% compared to the third quarter of last year and up 7% sequentially. We have staffing operations in 100 locations in 18 countries outside the US International staffing operations represent 28% of total staffing revenues. 
Protiviti revenues were $99 million during the third quarter, up 2% from a year ago, and up 8% from the second quarter of this year on a same day basis. Formed in 2002 Protiviti is a global business consulting and internal audit firm providing risk, advisory and transaction services. It has 60 locations in 16 countries, and accounts for 12% of total RHI revenues. Protiviti’s international operations represent 25% of total Protiviti revenues.
Turning to gross margin, gross margin in our temporary and consulting staffing operations was $225 million in the third quarter or 34.1% of applicable revenues. This is up from 33.5% one year ago, and unchanged from the 34.1% reported last quarter. Overall staffing gross margin during the third quarter was $282 million or 39.3% of staffing revenues. This compares to 38.1% of revenues one year ago, and 39.6% of revenues in the second quarter of this year. The mix of permanent placement revenues directly impacts overall gross margin and represents 8%, 8.3% and 6.8% of revenues for the third quarter of 2010, the second quarter of 2010, and the third quarter of 2009 respectively.
Protiviti gross margin was $27 million in the third quarter or 27% of Protiviti revenues. This compares to 24% of its revenues in the second quarter of this year. The increase is due primarily to higher chargeability. Staffing SG&A cost during the quarter were $245 million or 34.2% of staffing revenues. This compares to $223 million or 35.4% of revenues for the third quarter of last year, and $238 million or 35.3% of revenues for the second quarter of this year. The decline as a percent of revenues relates to the absence of litigation costs, which were expensed last quarter. SG&A cost for Protiviti during the quarter were $27 million or 26.9% of revenues. This compares to $26 million or 26.8% of revenues for the third quarter of last year, and $29 million or 31.2% of revenues for the second quarter of this year. This decline as a percentage of revenue also relates to the absence of prior quarter litigation cost.
Turning to operating income, third quarter operating income for our staffing divisions was $37 million or 5.2% of staffing revenues. The temporary and consulting divisions contributed $32 million of this amount or 4.8% of applicable revenues. Third quarter operating income for our permanent placement division was $5 million or 8.9% of applicable revenues. Operating income was $113,000 for Protiviti in the third quarter compared to an operating loss of $6.8 million in the second quarter of this year. The improvement relates primarily to the $5.7 million increase in Protiviti revenues during the quarter. Turning to accounts receivable, at the end of the third quarter, accounts receivable were $428 million with implied days sales outstanding of 47.6 days compared to 45.7 days at the end of last year's third quarter.
Now guidance, we observed the following business trends during the third quarter and the first weeks of October. On a same day sequential basis, revenues from our temporary and consulting divisions increased in July, increased in August, and increased again in September. Revenues for our permanent placement operations decreased in July, increased in August, and increased again in September. During the first two weeks of October, revenues from our temporary and consulting businesses were up 13% compared to the same period last year. 
For the first three weeks of October, revenues from our permanent placement division were up 10% compared to the same period last year. As we said before, we would caution against reading too much into perm trends over these short time periods. 
Taking into account these trends, we offer the following fourth quarter guidance, revenues, $800 million to $850 million; income per share, $0.12 to $0.18. As we've noted in the past, our guidance does not include any amounts for the possible settlement of outstanding legal claims.
As you know, we limit our guidance to one quarter. The estimates we provided on this call are subject to the risks mentioned in today’s press release. Max?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. As I noted earlier on the call, we were pleased to see broad based improvement throughout our operations. We saw higher demand for our services and higher revenues in all of our staffing divisions and Protiviti both on a year-over-year b
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. As I noted earlier on the call, we were pleased to see broad based improvement throughout our operations. We saw higher demand for our services and higher revenues in all of our staffing divisions and Protiviti both on a year-over-year basis and sequentially. Unemployment rates in United States remain high, but it has been our experience that companies do appear to be more open to hiring on both the temporary and full time basis. As business demand grows, the first course of action for many companies is often to bring in temporary workers, which keeps their labor cost variable. We have seen this pattern for several quarters now. For companies that made deeper personnel cuts and we believe many companies made severe cuts last year, their teams are now too lean in some cases. This makes them more likely to hire full time personnel at the first sign of improving business conditions and we have witnessed this in our permanent placement division.
Hiring demand has improved here and outside the United States, as Keith indicated, revenues for our non-US staffing operations were up 11% from the third quarter of 2009, and up 8% sequentially from the second quarter. We have emerged strongly from past recessions and we believe we are well positioned today. Our field teams are eager to take advantage of more favorable business conditions. We also were pleased to see higher revenues in Protiviti. Protiviti has continued to diversify its service offerings and clients are responding favorably. We see business opportunities in helping companies navigate the various financial reform measures that have either been introduced or are in process around the world in response to the global financial crisis.
We also see potential in Protiviti’s information technology practice, which is working with companies in areas such as IT security and privacy, IT applications controls, and infrastructure management. Protiviti and our staffing brands also are working together more frequently on joint projects for clients and bringing a full suite of staffing and consulting services to those clients. 
At this time Keith and I will be happy to respond to your questions. We ask that you please limit yourself as is usual to one question and a single follow-up as needed. If you have additional question we will certainly try to return to you later in the call. Thank you.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: (Operator Instructions) And your first question will come from the line of Mark Marcon with R. W. Baird. Your line is now open.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the outlook for Protiviti. Nice progress here in terms of the sequential revenue growth. Can you give us a little bit of a sense of if things continue and I guess what's embedded first of all in your ov
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about the outlook for Protiviti. Nice progress here in terms of the sequential revenue growth. Can you give us a little bit of a sense of if things continue and I guess what's embedded first of all in your overall guidance for Protiviti for the fourth quarter, and then if things continue, how should we think about the profitability levels of Protiviti as we go out one or two years?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, regarding what's embedded into the guidance for Protiviti. Remember that there'll be three fewer billing days in the fourth quarter than in the third. Protiviti is more impacted by the holidays as their clients, many of them, are shutdown betw
componenttext:
Well, Mark, regarding what's embedded into the guidance for Protiviti. Remember that there'll be three fewer billing days in the fourth quarter than in the third. Protiviti is more impacted by the holidays as their clients, many of them, are shutdown between Christmas and New Years, and because if they're not open, our staff can't work. So for that reason our guidance would be that the revenues would be a little lighter, not a lot lighter, but a little lighter in the fourth quarter than in the third, but you also get some payroll relief for those same reasons. Our guidance would say that the operating income from Protiviti would be about the same, maybe a little higher. Clearly, there has been a lot of improvement from the first half of the year both in the US and outside the US 
As to profitability, Protiviti had solid double digit margins in their past. Clearly the objective is to get back to double digit operating margins. Given where we've come, it's nice to be in the black again. It's nice to be forecasting that we'll stay in the black. The challenge will be the seasonal slowness that typically happens in the first quarter, and we're already working hard with our cost structure which is more variable as we speak to try to deal with that, but the improvement we've seen for several quarters now in Protiviti continued into this quarter and is expected to continue into the quarter we're in.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, can you talk a little bit about the timing of some of these initiatives that could come through in terms of financial reform, as well as potentially some fallout from the mortgage mess that the banks are experiencing?
componenttext: So, can you talk a little bit about the timing of some of these initiatives that could come through in terms of financial reform, as well as potentially some fallout from the mortgage mess that the banks are experiencing?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the financial services is Protiviti's largest industry group, so they are quite well represented there. There are lots of laws and regulations yet to be defined with the Frank-Dodd Act. So that I'm not sure there is a huge amount of real specific me
componenttext: Well, the financial services is Protiviti's largest industry group, so they are quite well represented there. There are lots of laws and regulations yet to be defined with the Frank-Dodd Act. So that I'm not sure there is a huge amount of real specific meat on that bone as we speak. That said, they are very active in the regulatory environment, anti-money laundering comes to the mind, but we believe Protiviti is very well positioned in financial services and will get more than its share of that business as those opportunities arise.

Do you feel like all the strength here, or relative strength is coming on the wage side, or do you feel like you are starting to get some pricing power now that volumes have returned pretty much in all your businesses and what would temp gross margin be implied in the fourth quarter guidance?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: During the quarter, our temp to hire conversions were actually up 19 basis points versus the second quarter. That offset, the absence of the workers’ comp credit that we had last quarter, which didn’t repeat, and our pay bill spreads were slightly sma
componenttext: During the quarter, our temp to hire conversions were actually up 19 basis points versus the second quarter. That offset, the absence of the workers’ comp credit that we had last quarter, which didn’t repeat, and our pay bill spreads were slightly smaller this quarter than last, but the conversion increase offset the other two such that they were flat. It would be our hope in the fourth quarter that we’d stay in that flat range again, but understand that conversions are somewhat volatile, so there could be some variability there.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Could you talk a little about pricing power?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Year-over-year, our bill rates were down 3.9%, but sequentially they were only down 0.4%. We are actually beginning to see increases in tech and to a lesser extent office administration, which are the earlier participants in the up cycle for us. So we’r
componenttext: Year-over-year, our bill rates were down 3.9%, but sequentially they were only down 0.4%. We are actually beginning to see increases in tech and to a lesser extent office administration, which are the earlier participants in the up cycle for us. So we’re cautiously optimistic on gross margins. We felt like we’ve managed them reasonably well including absorbing the higher state unemployment cost at this point, and conversions are still very much at the low end of historical range, so we hope there is upside as well there.

componenttext: So price should follow volume?

componenttextpreview: Price should follow volume. I think, one can make a case that one of the impacts of the high unemployment rate might be that prices lag more than traditionally, but that said that same phenomenon impacts pay rates and it's the differentials that's more im
componenttext: Price should follow volume. I think, one can make a case that one of the impacts of the high unemployment rate might be that prices lag more than traditionally, but that said that same phenomenon impacts pay rates and it's the differentials that's more important than the absolute.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you give us the tax rate that you expect for Q4 and just give a little color about what's going on there given that's it's been moving around? And then also just on perm, can you give a little more color on what your Q4 guidance implies for perm, an
componenttext: Could you give us the tax rate that you expect for Q4 and just give a little color about what's going on there given that's it's been moving around? And then also just on perm, can you give a little more color on what your Q4 guidance implies for perm, and specifically address how you're thinking about the tougher comps?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, on the tax rate as we've talked about for a few quarters now, the global composition of our income and some of the foreign locations, we still have small losses, all impact our weighted average tax rate. So 42% to 45% for the near term probably isn'
componenttext:
Well, on the tax rate as we've talked about for a few quarters now, the global composition of our income and some of the foreign locations, we still have small losses, all impact our weighted average tax rate. So 42% to 45% for the near term probably isn't a bad estimate, and again there is more volatility to that than there traditionally would be because of the relative importance of foreign operations earnings or lack thereof. 
As to perm and guidance, the fourth quarter seasonally is always a little bit softer in perm than the other quarters. Companies run out of hiring budget. Companies begin to work on their following year hiring budget and throttle back a bit on their full time hiring. There is the December effect and we've lived through over 20 Decembers and Decembers are particularly hard to predict in perm. We've had great ones; we've had some not so great ones. So there is probably more uncertainty with our perm component of our guidance than any other one line of business. But that said, our people remain bullish on perm. It's just the typical fourth quarter jitters.

componenttextpreview: I’d say a couple of things. Seasonally, DSOs always stretch out a little bit during these months as our clients' accounts payable departments aren’t as available as they are on holiday. Further our revenues were particularly back-loaded this quarter.
componenttext: I’d say a couple of things. Seasonally, DSOs always stretch out a little bit during these months as our clients' accounts payable departments aren’t as available as they are on holiday. Further our revenues were particularly back-loaded this quarter. September was particularly strong. If you just do the math, if you’ve got the revenues that are back ended that has the impact, and that’s a good thing to impact your DSO.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us some comment on, you talked about the perm side of SG&A and you gave some extra comp there. What are you doing on the temp side, are you at a point where you’re going to start looking at new offices and staffing up existing offices, what
componenttext: Can you give us some comment on, you talked about the perm side of SG&A and you gave some extra comp there. What are you doing on the temp side, are you at a point where you’re going to start looking at new offices and staffing up existing offices, what's kind of the investment philosophy at this point in the business?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the temp side, we are beginning to add the headcount. I’d say we added mid-single digits to our headcount during the quarter that was tech related, first, and our smaller Accountemps operations where growth begin to kick in, where we felt like we wer
componenttext:
On the temp side, we are beginning to add the headcount. I’d say we added mid-single digits to our headcount during the quarter that was tech related, first, and our smaller Accountemps operations where growth begin to kick in, where we felt like we were understaffed, so we did add to our staff during the quarter, given the results that we had. Along those lines, I would make a couple of points. This is the fastest recovery, we've ever experienced, post downturn. 
Our temp business is 20% above its lows versus at the same time in the last up cycle it was still flat relative to the lows. Our perm business is 40% above the lows versus same time last cycle it was also flat versus the lows. Those things said, our temp business is still only 70% of its prior peak. Our perm business is only 50% of its prior peak and many make the case that prior peaks will well be exceeded in this cycle because of the secular shifts. I would also point out there is a lot of discussion about the late cycle or later cycle participation of accounting and finance, and we're happy to report that the lag between accounting and office administrative as an example is the shortest lag we've ever experienced. 
This time around there was a four to five month lag between when OfficeTeam went year-over-year positive in revenues and when Accountemps went year-over-year positive. In the last cycle that lag was 9 to 10 months. So for all of those positive reasons, we've begun to add to headcount starting with technology and secondly backfilling the locations that we felt got a little too small in Accountemps.

componenttextpreview: I'd say the trends in the US, there's more seasonality in the US, so we got some SOX lift during the quarter, certainly not the traditional SOX lift, and SOX year-over-year was still down in Protiviti as was expected. We're seeing a lot of strength on the
componenttext: I'd say the trends in the US, there's more seasonality in the US, so we got some SOX lift during the quarter, certainly not the traditional SOX lift, and SOX year-over-year was still down in Protiviti as was expected. We're seeing a lot of strength on the IT side, security, privacy, application controls, as Max talked about, so very strong in the US Outside the US, you had the Europe August impact which clearly negatively impacts their numbers and comparisons, but overall we're quite pleased with the path that Protiviti has been on that has improved quarter-over-quarter for several quarters in a row.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then as a separate follow-up, last quarter, you had broken out Accountemps into two halves, where you had given us some indication on transactional accounting and staff accounting. Could you give an update for how those two halves performed during the thi
componenttext: Then as a separate follow-up, last quarter, you had broken out Accountemps into two halves, where you had given us some indication on transactional accounting and staff accounting. Could you give an update for how those two halves performed during the third quarter?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the accounting operations or the lower scaled part continued to perform well, but what really came on was the finance or staff accounting side which was running much harder this quarter, which includes credit and collections, professionals, budget a
componenttext:
Well, the accounting operations or the lower scaled part continued to perform well, but what really came on was the finance or staff accounting side which was running much harder this quarter, which includes credit and collections, professionals, budget analysts. 
It's frankly a very traditional recovery to see the transactional positions pick up first and the hire level or the staff level positions pick up after that, and I would say that Management Resources follow that same trend, where we're seeing project work in accounting get traction a little later than did the accounting operations or transactional positions. But very traditional in the timing of when those kick in.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tobey Sommer with SunTrust. Your line is now open.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Staying on the Accountemps section, can you talk about what your view as to why the lag is four to five months this cycle versus 9 to 10 months traditionally?
componenttext: Staying on the Accountemps section, can you talk about what your view as to why the lag is four to five months this cycle versus 9 to 10 months traditionally?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, there is a greater awareness everywhere that you want variable labor cost. That using temporary is an effective way to do that. With unemployment rates like they are the quality of the supply of temporaries has never been better. So at the very t
componenttext: I think, there is a greater awareness everywhere that you want variable labor cost. That using temporary is an effective way to do that. With unemployment rates like they are the quality of the supply of temporaries has never been better. So at the very time you want more cost variability, you have the best people available ever. And for that reason on a secular basis people are using more temporaries.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. In terms of the international staffing, can you speak to any areas of particular strength or weakness or add any color in terms of trends there?
componenttext: Great. In terms of the international staffing, can you speak to any areas of particular strength or weakness or add any color in terms of trends there?

componenttextpreview: Sure, I'd say Australia was our strongest market. In Europe, we were led by Germany, but the UK, France and Belgium were solid. So overall doing well outside the US, and Australia for widely documented natural resource rich reasons is leading the group.
componenttext: Sure, I'd say Australia was our strongest market. In Europe, we were led by Germany, but the UK, France and Belgium were solid. So overall doing well outside the US, and Australia for widely documented natural resource rich reasons is leading the group.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, given that the lion share of our clients are small to middle size businesses, I think, you can pretty much take our numbers as a proxy for their behaviors. While we do have some exposure to larger clients, it's well less than half relative to small
componenttext: Well, given that the lion share of our clients are small to middle size businesses, I think, you can pretty much take our numbers as a proxy for their behaviors. While we do have some exposure to larger clients, it's well less than half relative to small to middle size businesses. So clearly, they are using more temporaries. Now whether they are getting more confident about their prospects, we can argue, but it’s a fact they are using more temporaries.

componenttext: I know it's only been three weeks since the federal government passes $30 billion small business lending bill. componenttext: Well, certainly it’s a net positive. We've made comments on prior calls that the credit crunch or the lack of credit availability isn't the biggest issue, our small business clients have had notwithstanding the headlines. The biggest issue was demand for other services but that said, more credit is a better thing rather than not and we haven't seen any very specific demand come from that.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at the mix of where you've got off, it strikes me, it's sort of interesting that you have only a third as many technology offices as you do account temps or the perm business and given I think some people would argue there is better secular tr
componenttext: When I look at the mix of where you've got off, it strikes me, it's sort of interesting that you have only a third as many technology offices as you do account temps or the perm business and given I think some people would argue there is better secular trends potentially impact and certainly it's doing a little better today. Is that just a legacy issue, why is that and what's the plan? Do you have any plans to accelerate adding technology into some of the existing offices?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think traditionally, where we have offices is very candidate driven and that how many do you need to cover the candidate base, how far are they willing to travel and if you look at tech firms generally, you don't need as many satellite locations a
componenttext:
Well, I think traditionally, where we have offices is very candidate driven and that how many do you need to cover the candidate base, how far are they willing to travel and if you look at tech firms generally, you don't need as many satellite locations as you do for some of the other service lines. So I wouldn’t expect we would ever have as many locations in technology as we do in Accountemps. 
We'd certainly there is room for more than we have now and outside the US we certainly have countries that have virtually no presence in technology as we speak, so that’s Greenfield opportunity. So I am sure it’s less and it doesn’t need to be as much less as it currently is. But that said, I am not sure it will ever be the same number. You don’t need as many offices in technology, you can cover a wider area with a given office in technology than you can and as an example in OfficeTeam.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: That having been said, we are clearly focused on expanding our technology business in existing offices and perhaps some others. So I don’t want to leave that unsaid.
componenttext: That having been said, we are clearly focused on expanding our technology business in existing offices and perhaps some others. So I don’t want to leave that unsaid.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other metric we would follow more closely is, whatever our staff levels, rather than how many physical offices we have. We think there is a huge upside in the staff levels we can have in the geographies where we already exist. So to me the fea
componenttext: I think the other metric we would follow more closely is, whatever our staff levels, rather than how many physical offices we have. We think there is a huge upside in the staff levels we can have in the geographies where we already exist. So to me the featured fight is getting appropriately staffed to take advantage of the opportunity not necessarily having a bigger physical footprint.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given though, its sounds like Protiviti has got growing technology presence there and I am not sure if you are doing much of that in management resources. Can you give us any sense what maybe overall company mix of revenue would be more technology focused
componenttext: Given though, its sounds like Protiviti has got growing technology presence there and I am not sure if you are doing much of that in management resources. Can you give us any sense what maybe overall company mix of revenue would be more technology focused than either the accounting and finance or office segments? Is that getting up towards 20% and do you have any goals to have that more balanced?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you can quickly do research and determine that the overall technology staffing market is larger than the overall accounting and finance market. Therefore, we think there is a huge opportunity in technology. Traditionally, technology over the years
componenttext: I think you can quickly do research and determine that the overall technology staffing market is larger than the overall accounting and finance market. Therefore, we think there is a huge opportunity in technology. Traditionally, technology over the years has been contract programming at large Fortune 1000 companies at margin levels that are a bit challenged relative to our typical profile and so what we're getting after is how can we profitably approach the technology market and we're pretty encouraged with what we see so far.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about the shift on Protiviti towards more variable as opposed to fixed cost structure across the Group overall and how management resources plays into that?
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about the shift on Protiviti towards more variable as opposed to fixed cost structure across the Group overall and how management resources plays into that?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Protiviti has made tremendous progress in using contractors, consultants for management resources and frankly from all our divisions including RH Technology own its assignments. There has been a meaningful increase in the variable component of their l
componenttext:
The Protiviti has made tremendous progress in using contractors, consultants for management resources and frankly from all our divisions including RH Technology own its assignments. There has been a meaningful increase in the variable component of their labor cost which we're very pleased with because of the inherent seasonality that exists in Protiviti. 
Second half is always going to be somewhat better than the first half and so we'd like to be in a position that have our cost flex just as our revenues do. We're not totally there yet but we've made light years of progress in the last 12 months and we now have a double digit percentage of Protiviti's total workforce represented by contractors from our staffing divisions.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just real quick on the buyback it seems like you scaled up back a little bit relative to the second quarter, any thoughts on that going forward?
componenttext: Then just real quick on the buyback it seems like you scaled up back a little bit relative to the second quarter, any thoughts on that going forward?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Long term, we're committed to spend our cash flow on repurchases and dividends and even this year, year-to-date, we've done just that. Some quarters returned up the spigot, some quarters returned down the spigot but over a long period of time and in fact,
componenttext: Long term, we're committed to spend our cash flow on repurchases and dividends and even this year, year-to-date, we've done just that. Some quarters returned up the spigot, some quarters returned down the spigot but over a long period of time and in fact, if we go back five years, and you will find, we've spent almost exactly 100% of our cash flow on dividends and repurchases and we remain committed to do so.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Your last question comes from the line of John Healy with Northcoast Research. Your line is now open.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Big picture question for you, when I look at your results as well as your peers, we can clearly see the value proposition behind temp staffing has changing. I was curious to get your thoughts if you think over the next, I don't know, if it’s the next si
componenttext: Big picture question for you, when I look at your results as well as your peers, we can clearly see the value proposition behind temp staffing has changing. I was curious to get your thoughts if you think over the next, I don't know, if it’s the next six months or the next year or two. Do you think the value proposition of what you could do on the perm side of the business is changing and will your customer see you more as an HR partner than they saw in the past, do you think?

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I understand that our traditional middle market account doesn't have an HR department and when you need an accounting manager or a controller or a business manager, you can't go to HR and tell them to hire them. They effectively outsource that to us which
componenttext:
I understand that our traditional middle market account doesn't have an HR department and when you need an accounting manager or a controller or a business manager, you can't go to HR and tell them to hire them. They effectively outsource that to us which makes sense from them given their size. So I don't think that demand driver changes and if anything, gets stronger rather than not.
Hiring demand has improved here and outside the United States, as Keith indicated, revenues for our non-US staffing operations were up 11% from the third quarter of 2009, and up 8% sequentially from the second quarter. We have emerged strongly from past recessions and we believe we are well positioned today. Our field teams are eager to take advantage of more favorable business conditions.
We also were pleased to see higher revenues in Protiviti. Protiviti has continued to diversify its service offerings and clients are responding favorably. We see business opportunities in helping companies navigate the various financial reform measures that have either been introduced or are in process around the world in response to the global financial crisis. We also see potential in Protiviti’s information technology practice, which is working with companies in areas such as IT security and privacy, IT applications controls, and infrastructure management. Protiviti and our staffing brands also are working together more frequently on joint projects for clients and bringing a full suite of staffing and consulting services to those clients. 
At this time Keith and I will be happy to respond to your questions. We ask that you please limit yourself as is usual to one question and a single follow-up as needed. If you have additional question we will certainly try to return to you later in the call. Thank you.

headline: Robert Half International Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: All I'd add is that the typical small to mid-sized business person is fairly entrepreneurial. They have pretty sharp pencils, particularly in a downturn such as we've had and they understand the cost benefits of variable labor. So I think the concept of f
componenttext: All I'd add is that the typical small to mid-sized business person is fairly entrepreneurial. They have pretty sharp pencils, particularly in a downturn such as we've had and they understand the cost benefits of variable labor. So I think the concept of flexible staffing has been validated maybe in this recession, so I think that bodes well for the industry in general and for us in particular.
